seg.output: I grieve, my Henry, that my writings have fallen out such that they may appear to give rise to any kind of wrangling, from which I strongly abhor, seeing that I know that there should be comparison rather than altercation between the servants of God. Plainly and, as I think, truly I have proposed certain things which are confirmed by the Scriptures, namely, that the Church of Christ should not be subjected to excommunication by the magistrate (especially such as now are commonly in authority, where the supreme power is), lest they should, if they could, by some honourable or at least excusable means, abolish Christ's doctrine from among us, and that the magistrate and the Church are different things. As to both propositions, I have sufficiently declared what I mean. I know the magistrate to be the minister of God, nor do I speak only of the tyrannical, whom thou callest lame and maimed. I speak of the magistrate, whether he be good or bad: he is the minister of God. But a prince also may be good, who is not a tyrant, and who discharges his office aright, yet who is not enrolled among the external Church of Christ. Such was Cornelius, Acts 10 [1ff], Joseph of Arimathea, Nicodemus, and Gamaliel. And the thief on the cross confessed Christ, and was faithful, but was not in the Church. I call these different and distinct things, where the one may be without the other and subsist. Youth and age are different things, although a young man may become old, and an old man may become young again.

He administers the earthly and physical kingdom through magistrates and princes, and the Church and kingdom of heaven through the Apostles, to whom He says: "But you shall not be so" [Lk 22:26]. The Word preached by the Apostles is a physical thing. For speech is formed by the mouth, yet so that it proceeds from God and leads to God. So it is with excommunication.

He administers the earthly kingdom and the body through magistrates and princes, and the church and the kingdom of heaven through the apostles, to whom He says: "You, however, are not like that" [Lk 22,26]. He has entrusted nothing to the princes of the ecclesiastical affairs, but the sword. Whatever is purely corporeal, therefore, pertains to the magistrate, whatever pertains to the souls, to the ecclesiastical princes. The Word which is preached by the apostles is a corporeal thing. For the speech is formed by the mouth, but so that it proceeds from God and leads to God. So also of Excommunication. I do not write this, my Henry, to slander the words or deeds of the most learned man, but in my opinion no man's authority should be so great that it should prejudice the sacred Scriptures, nor should we be so bound by the words of any man that it would be permissible to freely dissent from him when the Scriptures are opposed. Moreover, it matters not to recount what the senate was like when it was entrusted to him, or what it is now, since it is known even to the blind. But I do not think that the Church of Christ is such a thing as the Republic of Plato, which can be imagined rather than seen. For I think the apostles had a true Church, not an imaginary one. Nor do I desire one in which there are no sinners, but I think that none should belong to the Church of Christ except penitents - when I say penitents, do I not recognize sinners? And none should be received who is a public enemy of Christ, but who professes Christ to be the only Saviour, and who believes in Christ.
No one seeks absolute perfection, no one seeks to be blessed in every way. But this should be striven for by all with a sincere desire, that we may attain to perfection.
Therefore I judge this speech to be pernicious: that because someone is not perfect in the Church, he does not therefore belong to the Church of Christ.
